topic.title: Changing hubs
topic.body:
Started using ZeroMe, saw only `WhiteHub`. I have only `Hello ZeroNet!` message and some likes. How can I choose another hub?

Please, don't ask why.

PS. Some people think that I don't know any other hubs. In fact, I know `WhiteHub`, `GreenHub`, `OrangeHub`, `BlueHub`, `RedHub`, `KaffieHub`. I just don't know how to move profile to another hub.

topic.title: Why do we need git-remote-zeronet?
topic.body:
Was looking around ZeroNet and found `git-remote-zeronet` script. It is used to push/fetch repositories to/from ZeroNet. But how is `git-remote-zeronet` different from:

```
git remote add /home/zeronet/data/...
# Hack hack hack
git push
zeronet.py siteSign ...
```

topic.title: Private sites
topic.body:
People, what do you think about private sites? I have 2 solutions:

---

1) All site content is encrypted, fileGet, fileWrite and fileStream (or whatever) decrypt and encrypt data in realtime.
**Pros:** Easy to implement
**Cons:** DIfficult to change source code because data is encrypted

2) When other peers want to download a private site, seeder passes encrypted data and new peers have to decrypt it locally.
**Pros:** Easy to change source code
**Cons:** Probably not compatible

Which one should I implement?

2_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj.body:
> [methane](#comment_9_1765rBagMqT5WbfJvixmJZi8tHyh6LHkvG): http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D can confirm if it work??

Of course it does!

> [wuzzap](#comment_2_1PcZwxWnxHJdWgdbsvZnivK8iGX9cdVvZg): my account has no password or private key? mhhh...

Why no? It has. Check out `users.json` file.

> [wuzzap](#comment_4_1PcZwxWnxHJdWgdbsvZnivK8iGX9cdVvZg): @ivanq this semms to be a list of all users with public keys. where i can find my private key?

If you own a site, there will also be a `privatekey` in that site's info. For each site, there is a unique pair of public and private keys (`auth_privatekey` as I remember). If you have ZeroID (and you have) you will also find a signature, a private key and a public key in the header of `users.json` (under `certs`).

> [sjsk20171018](#comment_3_16R9HXmcNRtk9MdNJCizqCQo4moZbE1hM8): help [...]

That's some user's problem who didn't use ZeroNet properly; don't worry.

1_136wmwLTBJoGTjXTAa7sWmXewn9P53EKML.body: A lot of interesting features... Waited for this release for a long time.

4_15XeFY67fYKCKxQPfeo246ELto2Gff1hAe.body:
> [bot](#comment_195_1KdnTJVBGzEZrJppFZtzfG9chukuMv8xSb): Haven't tried.. but prolly something like.. [...]

1. Don't use sites when making zites
2. ZeroNet has its own way to show different text for different languages (like ZeroHello - it is "SITES" and "FILES" for you but "САЙТЫ" and "ФАЙЛЫ" for me). The only problem is that I've forgotten that way. :D

> [bot](#comment_196_1KdnTJVBGzEZrJppFZtzfG9chukuMv8xSb): Or within Electron you have "locales" folder at the main app (exe) level.

The only problem is that ZeroNet doesn't support Electron. :D

1_12PByNvF6X2aF9wf68iSLFD1JDBKKAGTvo.body:
Files are cached by your browser, I suppose. You can just delete cache for http://127.0.0.1:43110 and your sites will show new data. If you have a dynamic site, you should probably load data with JavaScript.
*For developers:* You can probably disable HTTP caching in developer console settings.

8_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj.body:
Hey, @nofish, how do I generate `js/all.js`/`css/all.css`? I just cloned ZeroTalk from GitHub and now trying to fix a few bugs locally.

The problem is that in HTML I have:
```html
<script type="text/javascript" src="js/all.js">
```
When I sign or publish `content.json`, `content.json` changes, but `js/all.js` doesn't change at all.

> [nofish](#comment_917_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Install coffeescript compiler (included for windows) [...]

I had a problem with installing CoffeeScript (`pip install coffeescript`).
**Finally, I thought about `sudo npm install -g coffeescript` and that worked!**
@nofish, How can I add moderator permission to my site? Like, 1Asdf... can sign `data/users/.*`? Currently, only user and site admin can sign user content.

> [nofish](#comment_990_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Add the moderator's public address to "signers" value of the ".*" rule in the file data/users/content.json: [...]

Thanks!
@nofish, Is there a ZeroFrame method to get list of all optional files? And, can I pin a directory (recursively)?

> [nofish](#comment_997_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Right you can only list the downloaded files and you can only pin one file with one command

Okay, and if I read `files_optional` from `content.json` will I get the correct list?

> [xeven](#comment_4_1KcnvBNXUCsL6NsKDPB9HnjzdJsaLDzGUW): is there any way to make dynamic websites that dont include php or javascript?

Unfortunately, no. There are some sites like ZeroMedium (work in progress), ZeroBlog, ZeroTalk, etc. but they all rely on JavaScript. PHP and other server-side languages aren't supported at all.

@nofish, Is there a reason to split file to 6KB chunks in sendRawfile? I mean, is it a network problem or to save memory? I am implementing some very cool feature, so I would like to here that this is not related to memory. :)

> [nofish](#comment_1037_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): It does not split files into 6k chunks. It sends files in 512/1MB packages (depends of file size) and it uses 64k read buffer to reduce memory usage.

I mean streamFile, not getFile.

> [nofish](#comment_1038_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): There is no separate steamFile function anymore, the two functions were merged together. It depends on streaming argument if it using the streamFile or the getFile call

I meant line 425 in Connection.py. Anyway, I just misspelled 6KB - I meant 64KB of course.

And it's bad that 64k buffer is for reducing memory usage. Not the thing I wanted to hear.

> [nofish](#comment_1039_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Can you please explain why is it important for you?

I am trying to implement private site support in ZeroNet.

> [nofish](#comment_1039_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Can you please explain why is it important for you?

BTW, could you please look at https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1158 ?

4_1DCTA8rrSFeKX7CzieU3CYwCjGZ2hYvamb.body: A *really* great idea! I spent so much time trying to understand what's *hubs*, *merged sites*, *ZeroFrame*, *SQLite DB* (didn't manage to make it work yet), etc... Lack of documentation is so bad...

1_1GeF3xCLKvu92nMmgkT1NqUCyTwoFVbBGN.body:
Open directory where you installed ZeroNet, then open `data` folder. If there is no such folder:
1. Check if there is `data` in parent directory
2. On MacOS, check `/Library/Application Support/ZeroNet/` and `/Users/[your name here]/Library/Application Support/ZeroNet/`.
3. On Windows, check `C:\Users\[your name here]\Appdata\Roaming\ZeroNet` and `C:\Users\[your name here]\Appdata\Local\ZeroNet`.
4. On Linux, I don't know.

Copy `users.json` from that directory and paste it in the same directory on other computer.

1_15Q5U52Aqgjb66GkzhkGKDYgWsqR8TEkJG.body:
- If someone finds hub's private key, they can change everything in this hub.
- *You* can change *your* posts, comments, other data.
- If someone steals ZeroMe's private key, they can change ZeroMe's design, but not data.
- If someone steals ZeroMe user registry's private key, they can change everybody's metadata, but not posts and comments.

In fact, there is no point in hacking ZeroMe or one hub. ZeroMe can be taken down only if each hub is destroyed, because data is stored in multipal hubs.

Another way is destroying ZeroMe user registry. It has links to users' avatars, links to their hubs, usernames and users' descriptions. But most of this data can be restored from hubs.
- Avatars can be restored by searching `*.png`, `*.jpg`, `*.gif`.
- Links to hubs can be restored by searching all hubs.
- Usernames cannot be restored, but we can take them from `cert_user_id` prorperties which are something like `ivanq@zeroid.bit`.
- Descriptions cannot be restored too, but **who thinks about it when you have saved ZeroNet?**

> This is false. It's only true if the user has not given ZeroMe permission to edit their data. However, an attacker could edit the ZeroMe site to automatically change a user's posts when they visit it. Very unlikely, but still a possibility. However, with the ZeroMe key they do not have direct access to a user's post.

That's what I meant.

> Attacking the user registry will not harm ZeroMe's functionality. The only thing that'd be impaired is the 'all users' list.

Huh? ZeroMe will function normally, but new users will not be able to register.

> Profile info is stored on the user's selected hub. And not on the user registry. The info on the user registry is only for the 'all users' feature.

Ok. But descriptions are saved on user registry, too.

---

Anyway, if ZeroMe code is changed to remove posts and you don't visit ZeroMe, nothing can happen. That's the difference between ZeroMe and Twitter.

1_1LUy9iAxeWsj1DP5L8V17Yb2vo87FucjgD.body:
ZeroNet uses blockchain only for addresses - NameCoin. You can make money there only by downloading NameCoin client.

ZeroNet also uses Bitcoin signing keys, but only for verifying data - so, mining is not possible here, too.

---

To answer your second question:
> what does the "this is my site" switch mean? can i turn it on for other users' sites? can i turn it off on my own?
`This is my site` only opens a new menu, with `sign` and `publish` buttons, which allow you to give site's content to other people. But you still cannot sign other sites without their privatekey. And private key for *your* sites are held in `users.json` file.

8_1GgNo3CmxPd7n2pMSF3uyqf1XHvgtTUqCe.body: The main part of Reddit is subreddits, am I right? So, if we make subreddits as ZeroTalk clones and then make a main site (like reddit.bit) which has references to subreddits, will it work?

> [jayofthezero](#comment_7_16nArdxrSaNThNp83kL8E6NLL9WD98iUne): Makes more sense to create a merge site and each "subreddit" is a hub that people can choose to download and subscribe to. That way no one person has control over the content, but people don't have to worry about maintaining an up to date clone of the actual reddit clone itself if they don't want to. That also means people can freely make their own reddit clone if they want to but have it connect to the same posts, and hence, the same content and communities. [...]

I am a ZeroNet developer as well, a contibutor, wrote some libraries, etc. My idea was just simplified. But then, why can't we use ZeroMe as Reddit?

3_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof.body:
1. Its decentralization. Nobody can shutdown a site excluding the owner.
2. Open-source. *a)* ZeroNet is open-source, *b)* all sites are open-source.
3. Development environment. ZeroNet offers nice API and you can easily add some important features by sending a pull request.

> [xianc78](#comment_7_141zS75MupoDVjN4p7ivG9pXUXjAm9jLBQ): Also people can obfuscate their JavaScript code so nobody can see it.

Well, you cannot decode this code, but you *can* see it!
Moreover, some code can be misunderstood even if it was not obfiscated. :)

4_1CvyxRucf7BbDvGtFe5LayTS2qX88VN7Er.body:
> [akito](#comment_261_1F8omDpXyPsBfd9CBJ91o4Wv1AA2KxqMEY): It would probably take a longer time in total, but why not just do one first and the second one, too, once the first one is stable? Then you could choose each option, before making a new zite, depending on which one fits the zite owner most.

Using 1) would be a good idea if `content.json` and all other files wouldn't look like kdfolgiyqb34t98yvo9e4y53q even for author. That's because all content is encrypted on the file system.

> [akito](#comment_263_1F8omDpXyPsBfd9CBJ91o4Wv1AA2KxqMEY): Yes, I know. But you said, it is easy to implement. So why not start with this, so an option for private zites exists at all, so far. Then we can work on a better idea and implement that one in the future, once we are able to deal with its complexity.

BTW, it's "easy" to implement only if you choose if site is private when creating it. Otherwise ZeroNet must encrypt and decrypt all files each time you press a checkbox, and peers will have to download all files again. Moreover, ZeroNet has no page called "Create site" where I could put a checkbox.

> [akito](#comment_263_1F8omDpXyPsBfd9CBJ91o4Wv1AA2KxqMEY): Yes, I know. But you said, it is easy to implement. So why not start with this, so an option for private zites exists at all, so far. Then we can work on a better idea and implement that one in the future, once we are able to deal with its complexity.

Another note. Only content will be encrypted, not file size or directory structure (though you will have to bruteforce to find them). Is it OK?

> [akito](#comment_264_1F8omDpXyPsBfd9CBJ91o4Wv1AA2KxqMEY): I understood it this way in the first place, yes. I think the most important part is, that the content is itself is encrypted. The meta-data isn't that important in this case, at least not for now.

Well then. I'll try to implement this.

1_1GhYpibzrzQ9FZTeoeHxG297hgcqcv71X2.body:
> [semenarsonist](#comment_6_183gMpouB3uc5hjf6cuCc1oLz2neo8cCNs): I'm not sure if I see the point of your argument. Noone is preventing anyone from making a thread in a non-English language. In fact, pretty much half of the threads here are in Chinese so in a way this place already is a multilingual message board.

Huh, did you notice that `Main` changed to `English` in the header? I mean, people use it as a multilanguage board when it isn't. I think we should separate English board from Main board and make another site for this and (the most important thing!) don't show English board in ZeroHello: the reason people use Chinese, Polish, Spanish, etc. on ZeroTalk is that it is easy to start using: just click on a big button `ZeroTalk` in ZeroHello.
